thread.title: Eagle Point will refer marijuana issue, sales tax to voters
thread.title_full: Eagle Point will refer marijuana issue, sales tax to voters | OregonLive.com

author: The Associated Press
title: Eagle Point will refer marijuana issue, sales tax to voters
text:
Eagle Point's City Council voted unanimously Tuesday to refer marijuana sales, processing and taxation to voters in the November 2016 election.
The move essentially implements a temporary moratorium on the sale of cannabis inside city limits until voters make their decision.
On the same ballot, the council will ask voters to authorize a 3-percent tax on marijuana sales should they be allowed.
The Oregon Legislature decided in June to allow municipalities the option of banning pot sales and growing operations if 55 percent or more of their voters opposed Measure 91, the legalization law that passed statewide last November.
With 57 percent of Eagle Point voters opposed to Measure 91, resident Karen Carpenter said she agreed with letting voters decide the matter of allowing retail and wholesale operations.
"Pot stinks," she said. "Fifty-seven percent of our voters were opposed to it, therefore I think it appropriate to refer this to the voters."
Carpenter was one of a half-dozen people who spoke in opposition Tuesday to retail or wholesale marijuana operations in the city.
Resident Randy Sell agreed with the council decision and voiced concerns about personal use and backyard plants.
Sell said he felt there was a more lax approach to enforcing commercial laws when it came to marijuana crops because of a certain level of vagueness with state law.
"I wonder about zoning ordinances in this town," Sell said.
City Attorney Joe Kellerman agreed that determining zoning regulations for cannabis-related uses had yet to be clarified.
"All the lawyers are bemoaning how we're one of the most regulated land-use states in the nation, but they just ignored that whole issue when they passed House Bill 3400," Kellerman said.
"So it's going to have to be a city-by-city jurisdictional response until the state speaks on the issue."
Sell urged the council to address issues related to personal use in the near future.
"If I pile my trash 6 feet high and it stinks, I would get cited," he said. "If it's marijuana, they wouldn't know what to do because they don't know where they're going to go with it yet."
Councilor Ruth Jenks said the city likely would begin discussion in November about possible regulations for personal use and cultivation of cannabis.
Jenks was pleased with the council decision to give citizens a choice on the issue of marijuana sales.
"Given that 57 percent of voters said no the last time it was on the ballot, it only makes sense to put it before them again," Jenks said.
"And in coming weeks, we'll be talking about time, place and manner to address personal use."
-- The Associated Press
